Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥4 migraine days/month for ≥3 months (episodic); ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days for chronic (may use lower 10/4 threshold per clinician judgment)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 6-11: 70mg subcutaneous injection monthly (regardless of weight); do not exceed 70mg/month in this age group
Age_Specific_Contraindications: None major; standard adult contraindications apply; counsel caregivers on injection site reactions; avoid if history of serious hypersensitivity to erenumab
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Age 6-11: Most payers require 1 oral preventive class failure (vs adult 2); minimum trial 4-8 weeks; some accept AHS 2024 first-line recommendation
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: UHC: PDL same as adult. Anthem: Preferred. Medicaid: Varies by state; most require oral step. CHIP: Often aligned with Medicaid
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Standard PA pathway; document migraine frequency (diary), prior preventive trials if required, weight for dosing verification
Data_Source: FDA Label (2023 pediatric expansion): https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2023/761077s012lbl.pdf; 2024 AHS Consensus Statement
Notes: Most payer-friendly CGRP mAb for pediatrics due to FDA approval; first-line option per 2024 AHS for patients who have not responded to or cannot use oral preventives

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days for ≥3 months (same as adult ICHD-3 chronic migraine criteria)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 70mg monthly if <60kg; 140mg monthly if ≥60kg (weight-based dosing per FDA label)
Age_Specific_Contraindications: None major; counsel females 12-17 on contraception (drug not teratogenic but pregnancy should be evaluated); standard hypersensitivity precautions
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Age 12-17: Most payers apply adult 2-class oral preventive failure requirement; some (e.g., Cigna, select Medicaid) accept 1-class for adolescents
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: UHC: PDL same as adult. Anthem: Preferred agent. BCBS: Generally Tier 3. Medicaid: State PDL varies; most preferred
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Standard PA pathway; same documentation as adult; requires chronic migraine diagnosis (15/8 rule) and step therapy failure documentation
Notes: Weight-based dosing critical for adolescents; document weight at each visit; 140mg dose available for larger adolescents

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥4 migraine days/month for ≥3 months (episodic); chronic threshold may use 10/4 rule for younger children per clinical judgment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 6-11: 225mg subcutaneous injection monthly; OR 675mg quarterly (3 consecutive 225mg injections); weight-based adjustments not required per FDA label
Age_Specific_Contraindications: None major; latex sensitivity warning for prefilled syringe; avoid if history of serious hypersensitivity; injection site reactions common
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Age 6-11: Payers may require 1 oral preventive failure; trial duration 4-8 weeks; quarterly dosing option may improve compliance
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: UHC: Covered. Anthem: Non-preferred (Aimovig/Emgality preferred). Medicaid: Varies; often non-preferred. CHIP: Aligned with state Medicaid
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Standard PA; document migraine frequency, prior trials; note if quarterly dosing preferred for compliance
Data_Source: FDA Label (2023 pediatric expansion): https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2023/761089s010lbl.pdf; 2024 AHS Consensus
Notes: Quarterly dosing option valuable for pediatric compliance; latex allergy screening important

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days for ≥3 months (same as adult)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 225mg monthly OR 675mg quarterly (same as adult dosing; no weight adjustment required)
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Latex sensitivity (prefilled syringe); counsel females on contraception; standard hypersensitivity precautions
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Age 12-17: Adult step therapy typically applies (2 oral preventive class failures); quarterly option for compliance
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: UHC: Covered. Anthem: Non-preferred. Harvard Pilgrim: ⚠️ NON-FORMULARY 2026 (requires exception). Medicaid: State-dependent
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Standard PA pathway; if Harvard Pilgrim, requires Formulary Exception with MOA argument (ligand vs receptor)
Notes: ⚠️ Harvard Pilgrim 'Ajovy Cliff' affects adolescents too - prepare formulary exception

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥4 migraine days/month for ≥3 months (episodic); chronic may use 10/4 threshold per clinical judgment for younger children
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 6-11: Loading dose 240mg (two 120mg injections) on Day 1, then 120mg monthly; same as adult protocol
Age_Specific_Contraindications: None major; standard hypersensitivity precautions; injection site reactions; counsel on proper injection technique for caregivers
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Age 6-11: Most payers require 1 oral preventive failure; 4-8 week trial; loading dose must be documented
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: UHC: Preferred. Anthem: Preferred. Medicaid: Often preferred over Ajovy. CHIP: Aligned with Medicaid PDL
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Standard PA; document loading dose administration; prior oral preventive trials if required
Data_Source: FDA Label (2023 pediatric expansion): https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2023/761063s009lbl.pdf; 2024 AHS Consensus
Notes: Loading dose protocol same as adult; payers generally accept Emgality as preferred alongside Aimovig

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days for ≥3 months (same as adult ICHD-3)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: Loading dose 240mg on Day 1, then 120mg monthly (same as adult; no weight adjustment)
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Standard hypersensitivity precautions; counsel females on contraception; injection site reactions
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Age 12-17: Adult step therapy applies (2 oral preventive class failures); loading dose documentation required
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: UHC: Preferred. Anthem: Preferred. BCBS: Tier 3. Medicaid: State PDL varies; generally accessible
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Standard PA pathway; same as adult; document loading dose
Notes: Well-tolerated in adolescents; loading dose improves time to efficacy

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 75mg single dose as needed (uses adult dose; no pediatric weight-based adjustment established); maximum frequency not to exceed label guidance
Age_Specific_Contraindications: None major for adolescents; standard drug interactions apply; counsel females 12-17 on contraception; avoid with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
Off_Label_Authority: 2024 AHS Consensus Statement: 'Oral CGRP receptor antagonists (rimegepant, ubrogepant) are recommended as acute migraine treatment options. While FDA approval is limited to adults, clinical evidence supports use in adolescents when triptans are contraindicated or ineffective.' Also: 2023 Pediatric Migraine Guidelines support gepant use in adolescents.
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Off-label requires stricter step therapy: ≥2 triptan failures documented with specific dates and outcomes; or documented triptan contraindication (CV disease, hemiplegic migraine)
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Not on most pediatric formularies; requires Medical Necessity Letter citing AHS Consensus and triptan contraindication/failure. UHC: Case-by-case. Anthem: Requires exception. Medicaid: Rarely covered for <18
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Off-label pathway: PA + Medical Necessity Letter + AHS Consensus excerpt + documentation of ≥2 triptan failures OR triptan contraindication + headache diary. Expect 2-3 week review; prepare for denial and appeal
Data_Source: FDA Label (adult only): https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2023/212728s006lbl.pdf; 2024 AHS Consensus Statement (Ailani et al.)
Notes: Excellent clinical option for adolescent acute migraine but not FDA-approved <18; requires strong documentation for coverage; triptan contraindication is strongest bypass argument

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 50mg or 100mg single dose (uses adult dosing; 50mg may be tried first in smaller adolescents); may repeat once after 2 hours if needed
Age_Specific_Contraindications: None major; avoid with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors; hepatic impairment requires dose adjustment; counsel females on contraception
Off_Label_Authority: 2024 AHS Consensus Statement supports gepant use in adolescents when triptans contraindicated or failed; no direct pediatric RCT data but mechanism supports safety in adolescents
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Off-label: ≥2 triptan failures required OR documented triptan contraindication; stricter than Nurtec due to less adolescent prescribing data
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Rarely covered for <18; most payers require Nurtec exception first or will accept either gepant. UHC: Case-by-case. Anthem: Requires exception
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Off-label PA pathway: Medical Necessity Letter + AHS excerpt + triptan failure/contraindication documentation + diary
Notes: Less commonly prescribed for adolescents than Nurtec; similar efficacy profile; 50mg starting dose reasonable for smaller adolescents

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 5mg, 10mg, or 20mg intranasal; start with 10mg or 20mg based on severity; may repeat after 2 hours; maximum 40mg/24 hours
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Contraindicated in hemiplegic or basilar migraine; contraindicated with CV disease, uncontrolled hypertension, peripheral vascular disease; avoid within 24 hours of ergotamines or other triptans; serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs/SNRIs
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 12+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Standard triptan; often required as first-line step before gepants; 1-2 triptan trials typically required before advanced therapies
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: All payers: Preferred/Tier 1; generic available; no PA typically required. Medicaid: Preferred. CHIP: Preferred
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: No PA typically required; document response if later requesting gepant/CGRP
Notes: First-line acute treatment for adolescents; nasal spray preferred over oral for faster onset and in patients with nausea/vomiting

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 25mg, 50mg, or 100mg oral; start with 50mg; may repeat after 2 hours; maximum 200mg/24 hours (uses adult dosing off-label)
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Same contraindications as nasal: hemiplegic/basilar migraine, CV disease, uncontrolled HTN, PVD; serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs/SNRIs; avoid with ergotamines
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label but widely used; 2024 AHS and AAP guidelines support oral triptan use in adolescents; extensive real-world safety data
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Off-label but routinely covered; most payers do not distinguish oral from nasal for step therapy purposes
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: All payers: Preferred/Tier 1; generic; minimal PA barriers despite off-label status. Medicaid: Covered. CHIP: Covered
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Typically no PA; if PA required, document migraine diagnosis and response
Data_Source: FDA Label (oral adult): https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2017/020132s035lbl.pdf; AAP Guidelines; AHS Consensus
Notes: Despite off-label status for <18, routinely prescribed and covered; nasal spray has FDA approval so may be preferred documentation

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 6-11: 5mg (weight <40kg) or 10mg (weight ≥40kg) orally or ODT; may repeat after 2 hours; weight-based dosing critical
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Same triptan contraindications: hemiplegic/basilar migraine, CV disease, uncontrolled HTN; avoid with propranolol (increases rizatriptan levels - reduce rizatriptan dose to 5mg max); serotonin syndrome risk
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: First-line triptan for pediatrics due to FDA approval in young children; often required before CGRP therapies
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: All payers: Preferred; generic available. Medicaid: Preferred. CHIP: Preferred. Weight documentation may be required for 10mg dose
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Minimal PA; document weight if requesting 10mg dose in child <40kg
Notes: ⚠️ Drug interaction with propranolol important - if child on propranolol for prevention, reduce rizatriptan dose; weight-based dosing must be documented

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 5mg or 10mg orally or ODT; same weight-based guidance as younger children though most adolescents qualify for 10mg; may repeat after 2 hours
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Same triptan contraindications; propranolol interaction (reduce rizatriptan to 5mg if on propranolol); serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs/SNRIs commonly used in adolescents
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 6+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Standard first-line triptan; required before gepants in most step therapy protocols
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: All payers: Preferred; generic. Medicaid: Preferred. CHIP: Preferred
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Minimal PA barriers
Notes: ODT formulation helpful for adolescents with nausea; propranolol interaction relevant if on both for acute + preventive

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 6.25mg or 12.5mg oral; may repeat after 2 hours if needed; maximum 25mg/24 hours
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Standard triptan contraindications; generally well-tolerated in adolescents; serotonin syndrome risk
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 12+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Step therapy equivalent to other triptans; may be tried if sumatriptan/rizatriptan ineffective
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Most payers: Tier 2; brand may have higher copay than generic sumatriptan. Medicaid: Variable coverage
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Standard triptan PA if required; document prior triptan response
Notes: Less commonly prescribed than sumatriptan/rizatriptan; reasonable second-line triptan option

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: N/A - Acute treatment
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 2.5mg or 5mg intranasal; may repeat after 2 hours; maximum 10mg/24 hours
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Standard triptan contraindications; MAO-A inhibitor contraindication (avoid within 2 weeks); serotonin syndrome risk
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for age 12+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Alternative nasal triptan to sumatriptan; may be preferred if sumatriptan nasal ineffective
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Variable coverage; brand name; sumatriptan nasal often required first. Medicaid: Variable
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: May require PA documenting sumatriptan nasal failure
Notes: Alternative nasal option; helpful if sumatriptan causes side effects

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days for ≥3 months OR ≥4 migraine days/month (episodic prevention)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: Start 25mg daily, titrate by 25mg weekly to target 50-100mg/day in 2 divided doses; maximum 200mg/day; slower titration reduces cognitive side effects
Age_Specific_Contraindications: ⚠️ CRITICAL: FDA Black Box for birth defects (cleft lip/palate). Age 12-17 females: Mandatory contraception counseling; document pregnancy test if sexually active. Nephrolithiasis risk; metabolic acidosis; cognitive slowing ('dopamax'); weight loss; paresthesias; acute myopia/glaucoma (rare)
Off_Label_Authority: N/A - FDA approved for migraine prevention age 12+
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: First-line oral preventive for step therapy; 8-week trial typically required before CGRP; some payers accept 4 weeks if adverse event
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: All payers: Preferred; generic. Medicaid: Preferred. CHIP: Preferred. No PA typically required for generic
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Minimal PA for generic; document titration and target dose
Notes: ⚠️ Teratogenicity is PRIMARY concern for females 12-17; cognitive effects may impact school performance - document and consider alternatives if grades declining

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥4 migraine days/month for ≥3 months; or clinician judgment for episodic prevention in younger children
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 6-11: Start 0.5-1mg/kg/day, titrate weekly to 2-3mg/kg/day divided BID; maximum typically 3-6mg/kg/day (weight-based dosing critical)
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Same as adolescent: teratogenicity (less relevant but counsel if approaching puberty); nephrolithiasis; metabolic acidosis; cognitive effects may impact learning; weight loss concerning if underweight; paresthesias
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label for age <12 but commonly used; 2024 AHS Consensus: 'Topiramate has demonstrated efficacy in pediatric migraine prevention trials and remains a first-line option despite off-label status in younger children.'
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Off-label may require additional documentation; 1 triptan trial often required first; 4-8 week trial
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Most payers cover despite off-label; generic preferred. Medicaid: Usually covered. CHIP: Usually covered with documentation
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: May require PA with weight documentation and dose calculation; Medical Necessity Letter if denied initially
Data_Source: FDA Label; 2024 AHS Consensus; Pediatric migraine prevention RCTs (see Powers 2017)
Notes: Weight-based dosing critical; monitor growth and cognitive function; less concern for teratogenicity but counsel approaching puberty

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days (chronic) OR ≥4 days/month (episodic prevention)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: Start 10-20mg BID or TID, titrate to 40-160mg/day in divided doses based on response and tolerability; target heart rate reduction ~10-15%
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Asthma/COPD: CONTRAINDICATED (beta-blocker bronchospasm); bradycardia; hypotension; diabetes (masks hypoglycemia); depression (may worsen); heart block; Raynaud's phenomenon; ⚠️ Drug interaction: Reduces rizatriptan clearance - limit rizatriptan to 5mg if on propranolol
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label for pediatric migraine but extensive clinical experience; 2024 AHS Consensus lists propranolol as first-line oral preventive option; multiple pediatric studies support efficacy
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: First-line oral preventive; 8-week trial typically required before CGRP; contraindication documentation bypasses step therapy
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Most payers: Preferred; generic. Medicaid: Preferred. CHIP: Preferred. Rarely requires PA
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Minimal PA; document contraindications if present (asthma = automatic bypass)
Data_Source: Off-label but supported by AAP, AHS, AAN guidelines; extensive pediatric safety data
Notes: Asthma contraindication is common bypass for beta-blocker step; rizatriptan interaction important to document

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days (chronic) OR ≥4 days/month (episodic prevention); also used for mixed headache disorders
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: Start 10mg at bedtime, titrate by 10mg weekly to 25-75mg nightly; some adolescents may require 100mg; give at bedtime for sedation benefit
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormalities (obtain ECG if >50mg); anticholinergic effects (constipation, dry mouth, urinary retention); sedation; weight gain; ⚠️ Suicidality Black Box warning for antidepressants in <25; overdose risk (tricyclic toxicity); avoid with MAOIs
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label for migraine but commonly used; 2024 AHS Consensus: 'Tricyclic antidepressants remain a mainstay of pediatric migraine prevention'; particularly useful in comorbid depression/anxiety/insomnia
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: First-line oral preventive option; 8-week trial before CGRP; often preferred if insomnia or comorbid depression/anxiety
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Most payers: Preferred; generic. Medicaid: Preferred. CHIP: Preferred. Mental health indication may ease coverage
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Minimal PA; mental health comorbidity strengthens justification
Data_Source: Off-label but supported by AHS, AAP guidelines; CHAMP trial data
Notes: ⚠️ Suicidality Black Box important to discuss with families; ECG recommended if higher doses; sedation useful for sleep-disrupted adolescents

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days for ≥3 months (uses adult chronic criteria)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 10mg, 30mg, or 60mg once daily (uses adult dosing; no pediatric adjustment established); start 60mg for episodic, consider 30mg for chronic
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Hepatic impairment requires dose adjustment; avoid strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers; constipation common; counsel females on contraception
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label; limited pediatric data; 2024 AHS Consensus mentions oral CGRP antagonists as options but primarily references adult data; Phase 3 pediatric trials ongoing
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Off-label: May require failure of injectable CGRP mAbs first in some payer protocols; or documented injection phobia
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Rarely covered for <18; requires strong documentation. UHC: Exception only. Anthem: Not covered <18. Medicaid: Generally not covered for peds
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Off-label PA: Medical Necessity Letter + injectable CGRP failure or injection phobia (DSM-5 documented) + headache diary
Data_Source: FDA Label (adult): https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2023/215206s003lbl.pdf; 2024 AHS Consensus; ClinicalTrials.gov pediatric studies
Notes: Oral alternative to injectable CGRPs; useful for needle-phobic adolescents; but coverage extremely difficult to obtain for <18; pediatric trials ongoing

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: Not applicable for routine pediatric use; would require chronic migraine diagnosis if used off-label
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Not applicable for routine pediatric use; if used off-label: 100mg IV infusion quarterly (adult dosing)
Age_Specific_Contraindications: No pediatric-specific contraindications identified; if used off-label: standard hypersensitivity precautions; IV administration requires clinic/infusion center
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label; 2024 AHS Consensus does NOT specifically recommend IV CGRP mAbs for pediatrics; mentions 'injectable' options but focuses on SC agents. Limited pediatric data.
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Not recommended for routine use; would require failure of ALL SC CGRP mAbs + documented reason for IV preference (e.g., severe injection phobia, SC site reactions)
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Not covered for <18 on any major formulary. Exception requires extensive documentation and is rarely granted.
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Exceptional circumstances only: (1) Failure of ALL approved alternatives (Aimovig, Ajovy, Emgality), (2) Neurologist + Pediatric Specialist co-signature, (3) Detailed Medical Necessity Letter, (4) Documented injection phobia or SC failure reason
Notes: NOT recommended for 2026 platform launch in pediatric database; use of Vyepti in <18 would be highly controversial; defer to SC CGRP mAbs

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days for ≥3 months (strict chronic migraine criteria required; would not use for episodic in pediatrics)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: 155-195 units per treatment cycle following PREEMPT protocol (31-39 injection sites); same as adult; performed by trained specialist only
Age_Specific_Contraindications: Infection at injection sites; myasthenia gravis or Lambert-Eaton (contraindicated); neuromuscular disorders; hypersensitivity to botulinum toxin; pregnancy (inadequate data)
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label for <18 chronic migraine; 2024 AHS Consensus: 'OnabotulinumtoxinA should be considered for adolescents with chronic migraine who have failed multiple preventive trials, particularly when oral medications are poorly tolerated.' Limited pediatric RCT data but case series support efficacy.
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Off-label: Requires failure of ≥2 oral preventive classes AND ≥1 CGRP mAb in most protocols; some payers require 3-class oral failure
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Rarely covered for <18; Medical Benefit (J0585). Medicaid: Case-by-case. Commercial: Requires extensive prior failures. CHIP: Generally not covered.
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: Off-label pathway: (1) Chronic migraine dx verified (15/8 strict), (2) Documented failure of ≥2 oral classes + ≥1 CGRP, (3) Medical Necessity Letter from pediatric neurologist, (4) May require peer-to-peer
Data_Source: FDA Label (adult chronic migraine): https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2023/103000s5318lbl.pdf; 2024 AHS Consensus; LCD L35172 (Noridian)
Notes: Reserved for refractory chronic migraine in adolescents; requires pediatric headache specialist; MAC LCDs technically apply to adult indication but clinical evidence supports adolescent use

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥4 migraine days/month for ≥3 months; off-label for pediatric migraine prevention
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 6-11: Start 5-10mg/kg/day divided BID, titrate to 15-45mg/kg/day; monitor levels (50-100 mcg/mL therapeutic range)
Age_Specific_Contraindications: ⚠️⚠️ FDA BLACK BOX - HEPATOTOXICITY: Children <2 at highest risk; liver function monitoring mandatory. ⚠️⚠️ FDA BLACK BOX - TERATOGENICITY: Neural tube defects, decreased IQ in offspring. ⚠️ Pancreatitis risk. Thrombocytopenia. Weight gain. Tremor. Hair loss.
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label; 2024 AHS mentions valproate as historical option but notes: 'Given teratogenic concerns and alternative options, valproate is generally not first-line for pediatric migraine prevention, particularly in females approaching childbearing age.'
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: Due to Black Box warnings, should NOT be used as step therapy requirement; if payer requires, document contraindication concerns
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Variable coverage; often covered but not recommended first-line. Consider alternatives (topiramate, propranolol, CGRP)
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: If used: Requires LFT monitoring documentation; consent for teratogenicity counseling; weight monitoring
Notes: ⚠️⚠️ NOT RECOMMENDED for females of any age due to teratogenicity. Hepatotoxicity risk highest in young children. Prefer alternatives. If used, extensive monitoring required.

Pediatric_Chronic_Migraine_Threshold: ≥15 headache days/month + ≥8 migraine days (chronic) OR ≥4 days/month (episodic)
Pediatric_Dosing_Rule: Age 12-17: Start 250mg BID, titrate to 500-1500mg/day divided BID based on levels and response; target trough 50-100 mcg/mL
Age_Specific_Contraindications: ⚠️⚠️⚠️ FEMALES 12-17: DO NOT USE UNLESS NO ALTERNATIVES AND STRICT CONTRACEPTION IN PLACE. FDA Black Box for teratogenicity (neural tube defects, decreased IQ, autism risk). Hepatotoxicity (less risk than <2 but still present). Pancreatitis. PCOS risk. Weight gain. Thrombocytopenia.
Off_Label_Authority: Off-label for migraine; 2024 AHS Consensus explicitly cautions: 'Valproate should be avoided in females of childbearing potential unless no suitable alternative exists AND reliable contraception is confirmed.' ACOG recommends against valproate in women who may become pregnant.
Pediatric_Step_Therapy_Variation: DO NOT use as step therapy requirement for females 12-17; document teratogenicity concern as bypass. For males, may be used but alternatives preferred.
Pediatric_Formulary_Notes: Variable coverage; often covered. STRONG RECOMMENDATION: Do not prescribe for females 12-17 due to teratogenicity.
Pediatric_Prior_Auth_Pathway: If used in males: Standard PA. If used in females: Requires pregnancy test, documented contraception, extensive counseling documentation
Data_Source: FDA Label; 2024 AHS Consensus; ACOG Guidelines
Notes: ⚠️⚠️⚠️ PLATFORM SHOULD FLAG THIS DRUG FOR FEMALES 12-17. Teratogenicity is disqualifying for most cases. Use topiramate or CGRP instead.
